solution.text:
The volume of the cylindrical pool \(= \pi \times (\frac d2)^2 \times (h) m^3 = \pi \times (\frac{8}2)^2 \times (2) m^3\)
\(= 100571.43\) L

content.text: Your school is building a cylindrical swimming pool with a diameter of 8 metres and a depth of 2 metres. How much water (in litres) will they require to completely fill the pool?

hint.text: Volume of a cylindrical container = \(\pi \times r^2 \times h\) and \(1m^3 = 1000L\)

solution.text:
Rise in water level = 1.5 metres = 150 cm = h
Area of base = Area of Triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2 = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 38^2\)
=\(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 1444 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=93679.5 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 93.68 L

content.text: The water tank in Rekha’s house has a base in the shape of an equilateral triangle with each side measuring 38 cm. It is filled with water till a height of 3 metres. She pours some more water into the tank and the new level is 4.5 metres. What volume of water did she pour into the tank? Use \(\sqrt{3} = 1.73\)

hint.text: Area of an equilateral triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2\)

solution.text:

Cost of painting the box = Rs. 1.2 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the box = \(1350 \times 1.2\)
= Rs. 1620

content.text: Latika needs to paint a rectangular box from the outside. The cost of painting the box is Rs. 1.2 per \(cm^2.\) If the dimensions of the box are \(27 cm \times 12 cm \times 9 cm\), what is the total cost of painting the box?

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 131 \times 30 + \frac 12 \times 54\times(131 + 101)\)
\(= 10194 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 4 km/hr = 4000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 10194 \times 4000 = 40776000 m^3/hr\)
= 40776 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 40776\)
= 6850368 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 131 m, b = 101 m, c = 30 m and d= 84 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 4 km / hr. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

hint.text: Remember that the area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times \)(Sum of parallel sides) \(\times\) height

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 10^2 \times 63 = 19800 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 19800 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 33 \times 22 \times h = 19800 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {19800}{33 \times 22} = 27.27\)
The new cuboid is 27.27 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 63 cm and radius 10 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 33 cm and breadth 22 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid?

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
Volume of the brick wall \(= 14 m \times 4 m \times 0.5 m = 28 m^3\)
Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 28 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 28000\)

content.text: Anjali is building a brick wall which is 14 m long, 4m tall and 50cm wide. Each brick is 20cm long, 10 cm wide and 5 cm tall. How many bricks will Anjali need to buy?

hint.text: Start by calculating the volume of the entire brick wall

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 29 \times (25 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{1232.5}{14.5} - 25\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(1232.5 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 25 metres and the width of the field is 29 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river?

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

solution.text:
Area of Garden = Area of Plot - Area of the House
\(= ab - cd\)
\(= (3952 - 48(17)) m^2\)
\(=3136 m^2\)

Therefore, the volume will double

solution.text:

V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi (2r)^2h = 4\pi r^2h = 4V\)
Therefore, the volume will quadruple

content.text: If the radius is doubled:

If the radius is halved :
V \(= \pi r^2h\)

Therefore, the volume will quarter

content.text: If the radius is halved:
A cylinder has a radius r, a height h and a volume V
The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 416 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(416 m^2\)
Therefore, \(416 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{416}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{4}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 2 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 66 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{66}{\pi} = 21 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 21\)
= 27.6 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(66 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 8950.86 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {18}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {18}{2} - 5)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {18}2)^2-\pi (\frac {18}2 - m)^2}\)
= 43.82 cm

content.text: You have set up a rain-water harvesting system at your home. A cylindrical container with a radius of 12 dm collects rain-water from your roof. solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 3799.71 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (8)^2 \times 31 - \pi (8-x)^2 \times 31\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{31\pi}=8^2 - (8-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (8-x)^2 = 64 - \frac{V}{31\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 8 - 5\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

solution.text:

\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 22 \times 23 + \frac 12 \times 50.5 \times 34 + \frac 12 \times 27.5 \times 16.5 + \frac 12 \times 22 \times 27.5 + \frac 12 \times 45 \times 22\)

hint.text:
Observe the shapes carefully and see if you can break them down into smaller shapes to make calculating the areas easier. Remember the following formulas:
Area of Rectangle: \(length \times breadth\)
Area of Square: \(length^2\)
Area of a Triangle: \(\frac 12 \times base \times height\)
Area of Parallelogram: \(base \times height\)
Area of Trapezium: \(\frac 12 \times (a+b) \times h\)

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 7392\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{7392}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{7392}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {7392\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 28 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 14 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 34496 cm^3\)

solution.text:

Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 20 \times 10 = 200 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 280000
